Investigation.name: VENERA 9
Investigation.description:
Venera 9 was the first mission to return pictures from the surface of Venus, and the first to go into orbit around another planet. The Venera 9 spacecraft comprised two parts, an orbiter and an attached descent craft and entry system. The orbiter will be described here. The orbiter mission acted as a communications relay for the lander and explored cloud layers and atmospheric parameters of Venus.
Venera 9 was launched on 8 June 1975 at 2:38 UT on a Proton-K booster from Baikonur Cosmodrome (Tyuratam). After two mid-course corrections, on 16 June and 15 October, the orbiter released the descent module on 20 October and performed two burns, one on 20 October and one on 22 October. The second burn put the spacecraft into a 1,500 Ã— 111,700 km altitude, 48.3 hour period orbit around Venus. The orbital inclination was 34.17 degrees. This made Venera 9 the first spacecraft to go into orbit around another planet. It acted as a relay for the descent module / lander and made scientific observations from orbit. The orbit was changed over the next few days to a 1,547 x 112,144 km orbit with an inclination of 34.15 degrees. After three months the transmitter failed, ending the mission.
